new_methods.method_text: Feature selection strategy: extracting symbols from 1:50,000 Soviet topographic maps that might represent burial or settlement mounds
new_methods.verbatim_quote: The goal of the work was to extract archaeological features from 1:50,000 scale Soviet military topographic maps dating to the 1980s. Available as georeferenced GeoTIFFs (from http://web.uni-plovdiv.bg/vedrin/index_en.html in 2008), each of these maps covers ca 400 sq km. We wished to extract symbols from them that might represent burial or settlement mounds in our study area (see Fig. 2).

sampling_strategy.sampling_rationale: Target symbols potentially representing burial/settlement mounds in Yambol region
sampling_strategy.spatial_coverage: Soviet topographic map tiles covering Yambol region study area

expected_information_missing: Symbol identification criteria (how to distinguish mound symbols from similar symbols)

new_methods.method_text: Data structure design: relatively simple records with point geometry, record number, plus ten attributes
new_methods.verbatim_quote: The records we sought to create were relatively simple: a point for the feature, a record number, plus ten attributes.
expected_information_missing: Specific attribute names and data types

new_protocols.protocol_text: Symbol recognition and digitization: volunteers locate target symbols (averaging 200 per tile, ranging 50-400 per tile) and create point geometries at their locations
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: Such symbols occurred at a high density, averaging about 200 per tile (0.5 per sq km), with counts per tile ranging from about 50 to 400. The mound symbols were moderately obtrusive; some aspects of shape or colour were shared with other map symbols.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Visual scan of map tiles to locate target symbols, followed by point placement at symbol location

parameters.symbol_obtrusiveness: moderate (some shape/color overlap with other symbols)

expected_information_missing: Symbol recognition training provided to volunteers
Reference guide or symbol key provided

new_protocols.protocol_text: FAIMS Mobile automated capabilities: applied SRS, rendered maps, provided layer management, enforced topology, displayed controlled vocabularies, recorded creation time/author, maintained data history, applied validation, merged multi-device data, exported to common formats
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: To support this workflow and make work easier for both project staff and participants, FAIMS Mobile automated a number of tasks and provided necessary capabilities. It applied the spatial reference system, rendered maps in the workspace, provided layer management (including a data entry layer), enforced shape topology, displayed pre-defined controlled vocabularies for attribute terms, recorded creation time and author for each record, maintained a history of all changes to data, applied validation to ensure record completeness, merged data from multiple devices, and exported data in common formats.
new_protocols.procedure_description: FAIMS Mobile platform automatically handles spatial reference, map rendering, layer management, topology enforcement, vocabulary control, metadata capture, versioning, validation, data merging, and export

new_protocols.protocol_text: User interface design: streamlined interface with map view (layer toggle, pan, zoom, shape creation) and form view (attribute entry/editing), search/retrieval functions, record validation
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: The digitisation interface itself was as streamlined as possible (see Figs. 4 and 5). Volunteers could toggle between a map view for geospatial data interactions and a form view for attribute creation and editing. In the map, they could adjust layer focus and visibility, pan, and zoom. Existing records could be searched, retrieved, inspected, and edited.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Two-view interface: map view for spatial operations, form view for attribute data; includes search and record management
ui_components: Map view with layer controls, pan, zoom, shape creation tools
Form view with attribute entry fields
Toggle between map and form views
expected_information_missing: Specific UI layout screenshots in paper (referenced but images not extracted)

new_protocols.protocol_text: Time tracking methodology: programmer timesheets, device-recorded creation timestamps for volunteers, staff journals for configuration/support activities
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: To measure inputs, we collated the amount of time spent by various participants in the process, including the student programmer who instantiated the customisation, the student volunteers who undertook the digitisation, and project staff who configured the system, supported volunteers, exported data, and checked for errors. Project records provided much of this data (timesheets from the programmer; record creation timestamps for students using the system), while project staff logged time-on-task for activities in journals.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Multi-method time tracking: timesheets for programmer, automated timestamps for volunteers, manual journals for staff

parameters.volunteer_time_calculation: Based on start and end times of feature creation (represents work time excluding pauses between records)

expected_information_missing: How pauses/breaks distinguished from active work time
Treatment of partial hours or estimation methods

new_protocols.protocol_text: Quality assurance: random selection of 4 maps (7% of total), staff review to count true positives, false positives, false negatives, double-marking, and classification errors
new_protocols.verbatim_quote: Finally, project staff reviewed randomly selected digitisation work completed by volunteers to characterise errors.
new_protocols.procedure_description: Post-fieldwork random sampling of completed maps for manual error checking by staff using desktop GIS
expected_information_missing: Random selection method (random number generator, systematic, etc.)
Staff member qualifications for error checking
Inter-rater reliability if multiple staff checked

new_protocols.protocol_text: Volunteer training: minimal training requiring only minutes before students could begin digitizing
trigger_text: Training and supervision of students took no more than half an hour of staff time across the entire season.
a simple and intuitive UI allowed students to begin digitising after only minutes of training
new_protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper states training took 'only minutes' and total supervision was 'no more than half an hour' across entire season, but provides no description of training content, delivery method, or materials in Methods section.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No description of training curriculum, delivery format, materials provided, or quality assurance of training outcomes
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess training adequacy or identify which aspects of the system/task required explanation vs were immediately intuitive

expected_information_missing: Training delivery method (demo, hands-on, written guide)
